name: tradescantia bracteata
description: It would be difficult to tell Prairie Spiderwort apart from the popular Ohio Spiderwort if not for its small stature. At just one foot, it is the shortest of the Midwest Spiderworts.   It successfully spreads by seed and by underground rhizomes in dry, often sandy, sunny prairies.  It may also be referred to as Long-bracted Spiderwort.
features: Pollinator Favorite: butterflies, bees and birds
Deer Resistant (Our experiences here in the Upper Midwest may vary in other regions; deer can respond differently to local conditions or seasonal variations.)
Recommended for home landscaping but potentially aggressive; could overwhelm small landscapes
